abstract: At 57, the author has noticed a few changes since his first cross-country bicycle journey, 18 years ago. On this trip, he's in less of a hurry, with a greater propensity for stopping to take pictures and enjoying the scenery.
snippet: At 57, the author has noticed a few changes since his first cross-country bicycle journey, 18 years ago. On this trip, he's in less of a hurry, with a greater propensity for stopping to take pictures and enjoying the scenery.
lead_paragraph: WOOSTER, Ohio -- Eighteen years ago, when I made my first cross-country bicycle journey, the ride from the Golden Gate Bridge to the George Washington Bridge took 75 days. Sunday was day 75 of my second transcontinental trip, and the distance I have yet to travel from Wooster, Ohio, to Manhattan -- 470 miles by car, probably another 70 or 80 on a bicyclist's more meandering path -- is one way to measure how I've aged. (Another is that my knees are stiff and sore; every morning I feel  little like the Tin Man from "The Wizard of Oz," pleading squeakily for his oil can.)
